docs.title: plasma_elongation
docs.text:
• units: None

  • tags: equilibrium, geometry, shape

Plasma elongation is a dimensionless parameter that characterizes the vertical stretching of plasma cross-section in fusion devices. It represents the ratio of the plasma height to its width, indicating how elliptical the plasma shape is compared to a perfect circle.

The mathematical definition of plasma elongation is:

\[\kappa = \frac{b}{a}\]

where \(\kappa\) (kappa) is the elongation, \(b\) is the plasma semi-height (half-height), and \(a\) is the plasma semi-width (half-width).

In tokamaks, which possess axisymmetry, the elongation is calculated from the vertical and radial extremes of a flux surface:

\[\kappa = \frac{Z_{max} - Z_{min}}{R_{max} - R_{min}}\]

where \(Z_{max}\) and \(Z_{min}\) are the maximum and minimum vertical coordinates of the flux surface, and \(R_{max}\) and \(R_{min}\) are the maximum and minimum major radius coordinates, respectively.

In stellarators and other non-axisymmetric configurations, the elongation must account for the three-dimensional nature of the flux surfaces and is determined by averaging the cross-sectional elongation over different toroidal angles:

\[\kappa = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \frac{(Z_{max} - Z_{min})(\phi)}{(R_{max} - R_{min})(\phi)} d\phi\]

where \(\phi\) represents the toroidal angle.

Elongation is an important parameter in plasma physics and fusion research for several reasons:

  • It affects plasma stability, particularly vertical stability
  • It impacts energy confinement time and plasma performance
  • It influences the maximum achievable plasma pressure (beta limit)
  • It is a key factor in determining plasma MHD stability properties

Higher elongation values generally allow for higher plasma currents and better confinement, but excessive elongation can lead to vertical instabilities that require active feedback control systems.
